content.description: Vague recollection of where we started as there are more than a few ways to do so. The obvious feature is the corner system that takes you to the junction with the left hand branch of the Wishbone. Good rock all the way. August 1985
content.protection: An alpine route for sure, though we found one small fixed tcu at one point.
content.location: The right side of the attractive Wishbone Arete on the South summit of Sacagawea. Descent to the south down the obvious ramp. If you're careful it can be done without raps.

content.description:
This route climbs a left-facing dihedral on the right of this face.

Mostly 5.5-5.8 climbing with one short 5.9 section. Protection is good.

Climb the dihedral for 4 pitches. Step around the of the face and climb 4 more pitches.

Some loose rock does exist.
content.location: From Titcomb Basin, scramble up to the dihedral.

content.description:
This route follows the ridge from the low point between Mt Helen and Sacajawea. The route I followed stayed very close to the ridge crest all the way up. Good clean rock all the way up, and spectacular views of Titcomb Basin and the Winds. I descended by down climbing the east ridge (4th class), then dropping onto the glacier and walking back to the start of the route.

I saw no evidence of human traffic on the approach, and not much evidence on the route (one rap anchor, one cairn). There were a few cairns on the east ridge. I can't see anyone walking into Titcomb Basin just to do this route, but if you're in the vicinity and have a day it makes for a fun adventure.
content.protection: At most a light alpine rack. This is a great route to solo or tandem solo.
content.location: Just past the north end of Upper Titcomb Lake, zigzag up to the low point between Mt. Helen and Mt. Sacagawea.

content.description:
From Titcomb valley, ascend to the S col.  Once on the ridge, turn south and traverse across the NE face to the summit.  We roped up for three pitches no harder than 5.4.  Would be easy enough to solo, but there is some descent exposure.  The summit has a couple false spires.  Scramble around to find the high point with the geo-marker.

Note:  This takes a bit of route finding but the climbing is easy and the rock quality is pretty good.

Descend via the same route.  We did two repels while descending back to the saddle.
content.location: This route goes up the NE Face.
